facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 167 and 168 of 1968 are appeals from the judgment and orders dated December 20, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition Nos. 139 and 182 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 167 and 168 of 1968. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated December 20, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition Nos. 139 and 182 of 1966.

facts.text: Indenture of Lease dated January 12, 1944 between Ruler of Korea State (lessor) and Sir Mukherji B. Dadabhoy (lessee) granted mining lease for 30 years over 5.25 sq. miles.

anchor.surface_text: By an Indenture of Lease, dated January 12, 1944, made between the then Ruler of Korea State of the one part, referred to as the lessor therein, and Sir Mukherji B. Dadabhoy, referred to as the lessee, of the other part, the lessor granted to the lessee for a term of 30 years, in companysideration of payment of rents and royalties therein mentioned, a mining lease of an area measuring 5.25 sq. miles delineated on the plan annexed thereto, with liberties, powers and privileges and on terms and companyditions therein set out.

facts.text: Lessee agreed to pay royalties at rates varying from 5 to 25 according to price of coal per ton under clause 2 of the lease.

anchor.surface_text: By cl.  2  of that Indenture, the lessee agreed to pay during the subsistence of the lease royalties at the rates and on dates set out therein. The rates of royalty varied from 5 to 25 according to the price of companyl per ton extracted from the leased area, that is to say, from 4 ans. per ton if the price was Rs. 51/- per ton to 25 of the price per ton at the pits head if that price was Rs. 20/- or more.

facts.text: On merger of Korea State with Madhya Pradesh, leased area became subject to Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, 1948 and Mineral Concession Rules on October 25, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On the merger of the Korea State with Madhya Pradesh, into the events of which it is number necessary for the purposes of this appeal to go, the leased area became subject to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals  Regulation and Development  Act, 53 of 1948 and the Mineral Concession Rules made thereunder on October 25, 1949.

facts.text: In 1952, Sir Maneckji agreed to assign the lease to the respondent-company.

anchor.surface_text: In 1952, Sir Maneckji agreed to assign the said lease and the benefits, powers and privileges thereunder provided to the respondent- companypany.

facts.text: Agreement dated November 6, 1952 between State of Madhya Pradesh and respondent-company granting consent to assignment in consideration of complying with lease terms including royalties.

anchor.surface_text: Since, under that lease, such assignment companyld number be made without the previous companysent of the lessor and since, by that time, owing to the merger of the Korea State with Madhya Pradesh, the State of Madhya Pradesh had acquired the said area and the rights in respect of it under the said lease, an agreement was made between the State of Madhya Pradesh and the respondent-company on November 6, 1952 under which the State of Madhya Pradesh granted its companysent to the said assignment for the unexpired period of the said lease in companysideration of the respondent-company agreeing to companyply with the terms and companyditions of the said lease including I payment of royalties to the State Government as provided therein.

facts.text: Mazumdar Award published May 25, 1956 awarded increased wages to colliery workers, leading to increased controlled coal price.

anchor.surface_text: An unexpected development in the meantime took place. Under an industrial award, called the Mazumdar Award, published on May 25, 1956, increased wages were awarded to companyliery workers. To meet the companysequent increased expenditure which the companylieries had to incur, the Government of India proportionately increased the companytrolled companyl price.

facts.text: Respondent-company representation to Government of India dated October 5, 1956 noted coal price increase from Rs.14.6/- and 15.6/- to 17.6/- and 18.6/- per ton.

anchor.surface_text: A representation made by the respondent-company to the Government of India, dated October 5, 1956 shows that the increase in respect of the companyl extracted by the respondent- companypany was from 14.6.0 and Rs. 15.6.0 to Rs. 17.6.0 and Rs. 18.6.0 per ton.

facts.text: Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, 67 of 1957 passed by Parliament on December 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On December 28, 1957, Parliament passed the Mines and Minerals  Regulation and Development  Act, 67 of 1957 under its power under Entry 54 of List I of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

facts.text: Amending Act 15 of 1958 passed on May 15, 1958; Act brought into force from June 1, 1958 by notification dated May 29, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Act was brought into force by a numberification as provided by S. 1 3  thereof, an amending Act, being Act 15 of 1958, was passed on May 15, 1958, By a numberification dated May 29, 1958, the Central Government brought into force the Act with effect from June 1, 1958.

facts.text: Section 30A inserted by Amending Act 15 of 1958 with retrospective effect, suspending application of sec 9(1) and 16(1) to pre-1949 coal leases.

anchor.surface_text: The Amending Act, 15 of 1958, by its sec. 2, inserted into the Act sec. 30A with retrospective effect. That section reads as under Notwithstanding anything companytained in this Act, the provisions of sub-section  1  of section 9 and of sub-section  1  of section 16, shall number apply to or in relation to mining leases granted before the 25th day of October, 1949, in respect of companyl

facts.text: Central Government notification dated December 29, 1961 under sec 30A directed application of sec 9(1) to pre-1949 coal leases with modification: royalty at lease rate or 2.5% f.o.r. higher than Second Schedule rate.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1961, the Central Government issued a numberification in exercise of its power under the second part of sec. 30A, by which it directed application of sec. 9 1  with immediate effect to or in relation to the pre-1949 companyl mining leases subject to the modification that the lessee shall pay royalty at the rate specified in any agreement between the lessee and lessor or at 2-1/2 of f.o.r. price, whichever is higher, in lieu of the rate of royalty specified in respect of companyl in the Second Schedule to the said Act.

facts.text: State Government order dated September 23, 1963 to Collector, Surguja to recover royalty at 5% from July 1, 1958 subject to min Rs. 2,47,000 per year, prior at old rates.

anchor.surface_text: It would seem that as a result of the companypanys representations and companysultation by the Central Government with the State Government, the latter issued an order, dated September 23, 1963 to the Collector, Surguja, directing him to recover from the respondent- ,company royalty at the rate of 5 with effect from July 1, 1958 subject to the companydition that the royalty amount should number be less than Rs. 2,47,000/- per year.

facts.text: State Government order dated October 1, 1965 partially suspended 1963 order, directed recovery from December 29, 1961 at lease rates per GOI notification.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government, however, changed its mind later on, for, by its order dated October 1, 1965 it partially suspended its order of September 23, 1963 and directed the Collector to recover royalty as from December 29, 1961 at the rates prescribed under the lease in accordance with the Government of Indias numberification No. S.O. 30, dated 29th December, 1961.

facts.text: Central Government notification January 1, 1966 directed lessees of pre-1949 leases to pay 5% f.o.r. royalty.

anchor.surface_text: However, on January 1, 1966, the Central Government issued a numberification under which it directed the lessees of pre-1949 leases to pay royalty at 5 of the f.o.r. price.

facts.text: State Government order dated February 11, 1966 instructed Collector to charge 5% from January 1, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, by its order, dated February 11, 1966, the State Government issued instructions to the Collector to charge royalty at that rate with effect from 1st of January, 1966.

facts.text: Controversy concerns royalty rate for period December 29, 1961 to December 31, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The companytroversy between the parties, therefore, is companyfined to the rate of royalty at which the companypany was liable to pay royalty for the period between December 29, 1961 and December 31, 1965.

facts.text: Collector served demand notices on respondent-company on January 25, 1966 for arrears at lease rates.

anchor.surface_text: On January 25, 1966, the Collector served upon the respon- dent-company demand numberices to pay the arrears of royalty for the aforesaid period at the rates provided in the lease.

facts.text: Respondent-company filed writ petition in March 1966 in MP High Court quashing Oct 1, 1965 order, rejection of representation Nov 19, 1965, and demand notices.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany thereupon filed a revision before the Central Government under the Mineral Concession Rules, 1960. That revision was pending when the companypany filed a writ petition in March 1966 in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh for quashing the said order, dated October 1, 1965, the rejection of its representation by the State Government, dated November 19, 1965 and the said demand numberices.

facts.text: High Court held that under 1961 notification, for leases with royalty >5%, pay 5%; rejected State's contention; quashed orders and notices.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention raised by the State as being inconsistent with the purpose for which sec. 30A was introduced. ... It follows from this that the petitioner-company which was, under the terms of its lease liable to pay royalty at a rate higher than 5 per cent of f.o.r. price per ton for the period from 29th December .1961, is rightly entitled to claim that under the numberification dated 29th December 1961, it cannot be called upon to pay royalty from 29th September 1961 at the rate stipulated in the lease granted to it but only at the rate of 5 per cent of f.o.r. price per ton specified in the Second Schedule.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court conclusions on construction of sec 30A and 1961 notification.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, we are in agreement with the High Courts companyclusions.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 168 of 1968 involves the same question.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 168 of 1968 involves the same question and our decision in that appeal, must, therefore, be governed by the decision in this appeal.

holdings.text: The operation of sections 9(1) and 16(1) was suspended as far as pre-1949 mining leases for coal were concerned. The second part, however, empowered the Central Government, on its satisfaction that it was expedient to do so, to direct that all or any of those provisions [...] shall apply to such leases subject to such exceptions and modifications, if any, as might be specified in that or any subsequent notification.

anchor.surface_text: The section falls into two parts. Under the first part, the operation of sections 9 1 and 16 1 was suspended as far as pre-1949 mining leases for coal were concerned. The second part, however, empowered the Central Government, on its satisfaction that it was expedient to do so, to direct that all or any of those provisions, including rules made under sees. 13 and 18, should apply to such leases subject to such exceptions and modi- fications, if any, as might be specified in that or any subsequent notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text divides sec 30A into suspension part and empowerment for phased application via notification with modifications to avoid sudden uniformity burdens.

holdings.text: The mischief which the Amending Act, 1958 sought to avoid was thus to prevent enhancement of royalty at one stroke to 5.

anchor.surface_text: The mischief which the Amending Act, 1958 sought to avoid was thus to prevent enhancement of royalty at one stroke to 5. As aforesaid, sec. 30A suspended the application of secs. 9 1 and 16 1 in relation to pre-1949 leases and authorised the Central Government to direct that all or any of the said provisions including rules made under secs. 13 and 18 shall apply to or in relation to such leases subject to such exceptions and modifications, if any, as may be specified in a notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history, Statement of Objects and Reasons, and ministerial statements show intent to phase royalty uniformity without disrupting coal production and economy.

holdings.text: On a plain reading of the notification, however, it is clear that what it meant was that instead of the rate flowing from the application of sec. 9(1) and the Second Schedule, a modified rate should be applied, that is, in lieu of the rate of royalty specified in the Second Schedule, royalty at the agreed rate should be charged if it was lower than 5, or at 2-1/2 minimum, whichever was higher. The notification, thus, did not empower the State Government to recover royalty at a rate higher than 5 in lieu of the rate chargeable under sec. 9(1) and the Second Schedule which provided 5 only.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading of the notification, however, it is clear that what it meant was that instead of the rate flowing from the application of sec. 9 1 and the Second Schedule, a modified rate should be applied, that is, in lieu of the rate of royalty specified in the Second Schedule, royalty at the agreed rate should be charged if it was lower than 5, or at 2-1/2 minimum, whichever was higher. The notification, thus, did number -empower the State Government to recover royalty at a rate higher than 5 in lieu of the rate chargeable under sec. 9 1 and the Second Schedule which provided 5 only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading in light of sec 30A power limit and harmonious construction preferring valid interpretation; modification to sec 9(1) rate (5%) can only lower it, not raise above.

holdings.text: The argument urged on behalf of the State both before the High Court and before us was that the notification clearly envisaged payment of royalty at the rate agreed to between the lessor and the lessee or at 2-1/2 whichever was higher. [...] The argument, in our opinion, is untenable as it is not borne out by the language of the notification itself and of sec. 30A and was therefore rightly repelled by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The argument urged on behalf of the State both before the .High Court and before us was that the numberification clearly envisaged payment of royalty at the rate agreed to between the lessor ,and the lessee or at 2-1/2 whichever was higher. Since, the agreement in the present case provided for royalty at graded rates which were higher than 21, the companypany had to pay royalty at such agreed rates. The argument, in our opinion, is untenable as it is number borne out by the language of the numberification itself and of sec. 30A and was therefore rightly repelled by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading rejected as it would exceed sec 30A delegated power and contradict sec 9(1) limit; prefer construction upholding validity.

holdings.text: The rule of construction that a court construing a provision of law must presume that the intention of the authority making it was not to exceed its power and to enact it validly is well-settled. Where, therefore, two constructions are possible, the one which sustains its validity must be preferred.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of companystruction that a companyrt companystruing a provision of law must presume that the intention of the authority making it was number to exceed its power and to enact it validly is well-settled. Where, therefore, two constructions are possible, the one which sustains its validity must be preferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to resolve ambiguity in notification: avoid construction making it ultra vires sec 30A.

holdings.text: The High Court, in our view, was right in quashing that order as also the demand notices issued in pursuance of that order.

anchor.surface_text: The section falls into two parts. Under the first part, the operation of sections 9 1 and 16 1 was suspended as far as pre-1949 mining leases for coal were concerned. The second part, however, empowered the Central Government, on its satisfaction that it was expedient to do so, to direct that all or any of those provisions, including rules made under sees. 13 and 18, should apply to such leases subject to such exceptions and modi- fications, if any, as might be specified in that or any subsequent notification.

The High Court, in our view, was right in quashing that order as also the demand notices issued in pursuance of that order. In view of our decision on the question of construction of the notification and sec. 30A, it becomes unnecessary to consider the second contention raised by the companys counsel that the order of 1963 amounted to a modification of the terms of the lease, and that therefore, the State Government could

anchor.surface_text: The mischief which the Amending Act, 1958 sought to avoid was thus to prevent enhancement of royalty at one stroke to 5. As aforesaid, sec. 30A suspended the application of secs. 9 1 and 16 1 in relation to pre-1949 leases and authorised the Central Government to direct that all or any of the said provisions including rules made under secs. 13 and 18 shall apply to or in relation to such leases subject to such exceptions and modifications, if any, as may be specified in a notification.

The High Court, in our view, was right in quashing that order as also the demand notices issued in pursuance of that order. In view of our decision on the question of construction of the notification and sec. 30A, it becomes unnecessary to consider the second contention raised by the companys counsel that the order of 1963 amounted to a modification of the terms of the lease, and that therefore, the State Government could

edges.explanation: Plain reading of notification undercuts State's argument that it clearly envisaged payment at higher agreed lease rate

anchor.surface_text: On a plain reading of the notification, however, it is clear that what it meant was that instead of the rate flowing from the application of sec. 9 1 and the Second Schedule, a modified rate should be applied, that is, in lieu of the rate of royalty specified in the Second Schedule, royalty at the agreed rate should be charged if it was lower than 5, or at 2-1/2 minimum, whichever was higher. The notification, thus, did number -empower the State Government to recover royalty at a rate higher than 5 in lieu of the rate chargeable under sec. 9 1 and the Second Schedule which provided 5 only.
e, therefore, two companystructions are possible, the one which sustains its validity must be preferred. On a plain reading of the numberification, ho

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our view, was right in quashing that order as also the demand notices issued in pursuance of that order. In view of our decision on the question of construction of the notification and sec. 30A, it becomes unnecessary to consider the second contention raised by the companys counsel that the order of 1963 amounted to a modification of the terms of the lease, and that therefore, the State Government could

The argument urged on behalf of the State both before the .High Court and before us was that the numberification clearly envisaged payment of royalty at the rate agreed to between the lessor ,and the lessee or at 2-1/2 whichever was higher. Since, the agreement in the present case provided for royalty at graded rates which were higher than 21, the companypany had to pay royalty at such agreed rates. The argument, in our opinion, is untenable as it is number borne out by the language of the numberification itself and of sec. 30A and was therefore rightly repelled by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of companystruction that a companyrt companystruing a provision of law must presume that the intention of the authority making it was number to exceed its power and to enact it validly is well-settled. Where, therefore, two constructions are possible, the one which sustains its validity must be preferred.
